thoughts.a: The input grid and output grids are the same sizes. The input grid consists of a black color background with a variety of different shaped objects, each of which fit inside of a 3x3 tile square. Nearly all of these objects are blue colored, except one, a plus sign shaped object, is aqua colored instead of blue colored. The output grid is very similar to the input grid, where the objects have kept their relative locations, except some of the objects have changed colors from blue to either orange or aqua. There must be some type of selection rule present in the input grid that tells us which objects have been selected to be which color. Notice that all of the aqua objects in the output grid are the same shape as the original aqua object in the input grid. That is, the only aqua objects in the output grid are plus sign shapes. The other orange objects are a variety of different shapes, but they seem to have something all in common with each other. They are always located in between two of the aqua color objects.  All blue objects that are located between the aqua color plus sign objects are now orange, and all the blue objects that are not directly between or located in a line between two aqau plus sign objects have remained blue. Thus the hypothesis is the following. The input grid will contain a background color probably black. It will also contain a variety of different shaped objects, probably blue colored, that are all aligned in a grid. In this case, each of the shaped objects can be contained fully in a 3x3 tile square, but that size may not necessarily needed to that specific size. One object in the input grid will be a different color than all of the rest of them, and in this case that color was aqua instead of blue. This object shapes is the selected shape. In order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over from the input grid the relative locations of all the objects into the output grid but some of the objects will have their colors changed. There are two ways that objects will change their colors in the output grid according to the selection rule. The first is that all of the shapes that are in the output grid that match the differently colored object, the selected shape, in the output grid needs to be changed to that different color. In this case, that different color was aqua, and that shape was a plus sign. The second rule to change the color of the objects is by identifying whether that object is located in a vertical or horizontal line between any two of the objects with the selected shape. If any object is located in such a position, that object should be changed to the color orange. We are not sure how to handle the case of a selected shaped object being in between two other selected shape objects, but most likely it would stay the color of the selected shape. The background color stays the some wherever it was originally located.
thoughts.b: The input grid and output grids are again the same sizes. the input grid consists of a black color background with a variety of different shaped objects, which fit inside of a 3x3 tile square. As expected, nearly all of these objects are blue colored except for one, which is an aqua colored object. In this case, the aqua color object has a shape of a donut, or a 3x3 tile square with a hole in the center of it. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid to the output grid while changing some of the colors of the objects according to the selection rule. In this case, the selected shape is a donut. Therefore, in the output grid, we need to identify all of the donut shapes and color them all from blue to aqua. The other way to change colors is that we need to identify any object, regardless of shape, that happens to be located between two of the selected shape objects. These objects should be changed to the color orange instead of blue in the output grid. In this case there are five such orange objects. All other objects should stay blue and the background color tiles should stay black. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid, the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.c: Input and output grids are again the same sizes. The nput grid consists of a black color background with a variety of different shaped objects, each of which fit inside of a 3x3 tile square. Nearly all of these objects are blue except for one, which is an aqua object. The aqua object in this case looks like an arch or a letter n. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid to the output grid while changing some of the colors of the objects according to the selection rule. In this case, the selected shape is an arch. Therefore, in the output grid, we need to identify all of the arch shapes and color these objects aqua. There are three total arch shapes in the output grid and all of these objects should be aqua. The other selection rule to apply is to identify all the objects, regardless of their shape, that are located between any two arch shaped objects. These objects should be changed to orange instead of blue. In this case, there are three such objects that need to be changed to orange. All other objects that were originally blue should stay blue, and the background color tiles should stay as the background color black. Because this is exactly what we see in the output grid the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.d: We apply the hypothesis here. The input and output grids should be the same size. The input grid consists of a black color background with a variety of different shaped objects, each of which fit inside of a 3x3 tile square. Nearly all of these objects are blue except for one, which is an aqua object. The aqua object in this case looks like an arrowhead pointing towards a single tile. Let's refer to this shape as the arrowhead. According to the hypothesis, in order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the input grid to the output grid while changing some of the colors of the blue objects according to the selection rule. In this case, the selected shape is an arrowhead. In the output grid we need to identify all of the shaped objects that are arrowhead shaped, and each of these objects should be aqua colored. There are five total arrowhead shaped objects in the output grid. The other selection rule to apply is to identify all the objects regardless of their shape that are located between any two arrowhead shaped objects. These identified objects should be changed to the color orange instead of blue. In this case, there are 10 total objects that are located between any pair of arrowhead shaped objects, and these objects should all be changed to orange color. All other blue objects that were originally blue should stay blue and the background color tiles should stay as the black background color.
